pros: I definitely recommend SBA. - Good culture. Nice people. Collegiality is real here. Top to bottom. - Integrity. Integrity is not only preached but it's shown. They lead by example. - Work/life balance. Vacations are respected. Work schedule is respected. They treat you as a responsible adult. - Benefits. Great. Even pet health insurance. - Office. Great space. Love working from here. I understand some people would want more days of hybrid work. This might not be important for some people but it's the defining reason when others evaluate a job offer. The company should look into it and be less resistant. - Efforts. This company makes an effort. They not always get it right but they try. They should however double their attention on items that have been needing fixing and are still outstanding.
cons: - Career Advancement. Pay at SBA is fair. It's not great, it's not bad. The only way to make more is to get promoted or moved to a higher position in another department. Promotion routes are not clear for several positions and the company loses and has lost talent because of it. Although a lot of effort (yes, a lot) has been put to change this, the general feel in the company is that it hasn't worked out. A lot of attention is put in cross-departmental movement, which indeed works well at SBA, but less is put on same-department movement. That recipe helps better entry-level position holders or generalists that can easily pivot. Not easy for specialized functions. The effort is appreciated but the problem remains. We are losing and will lose more talent because of that. Millennials and Gen Z are not as patient as prior generations. - Pay. The pay is OK. If career advancement remains a challenge, the company should start paying more. A mix of aggressive bonus practices and/or intralevel increases are a good start. - Flatness. Flat hierarchical structures contribute to the problems above. Create more levels. Or sublevels, for that matter. Offer a little bit more money by sublevel. It costs almost nothing for the company and it helps the employees to feel seen. The entitlement is real and it's here to stay. It's a generational thing. The company does not fix it by leveling up.
